definition: to make nothing of hardships
(negative prefix)/not/no
old variant of 辭|辞[ci2]
to resign/to dismiss/to decline/to take leave/ballad (archaic poetic genre)/variant of 詞|词[ci2]
surname Xin

(of taste) hot or pungent/hard/laborious/suffering/eighth in order/eighth of the ten Heavenly Stems 十天干[shi2 tian1 gan1]/letter "H" or Roman "VIII" in list "A, B, C", or "I, II, III" etc/ancient Chinese compass point: 285°/octa
bitter/hardship/pain/to suffer/to bring suffering to/painstakingly

sentences.english: Morning, light rain is still painstaking work of his sister.
sentences.chinese: 今早，小雨妹妹还在不辞辛苦的工作。

sentences.english: Some people start running with the hope that the pounds will quickly start melting away as they're pounding the pavement.
sentences.chinese: 有些人们一心想要减轻体重，开始了不辞辛苦的长跑。

sentences.english: He spared no pains to bring up the child.
sentences.chinese: 他不辞辛苦养育那小孩。

sentences.english: I truly hope that you can take the trouble to arrange another interview.
sentences.chinese: 我真希望您能不辞辛苦重新安排一次面试。

definition: to spare no effort
night and day (idiom); continuous strenuous effort
day and night/round-the-clock
make light of traveling a thousand li/go to the trouble of traveling a long distance
hardworking/industrious
to travel over land and water (idiom)
see 起早貪黑|起早贪黑[qi3 zao3 tan1 hei1]
to travel or work through night and day/to toil away for long hours
regardless of weather conditions/rain, hail or shine
lit. to spit out one's heart and spill blood (idiom)/to work one's heart out/blood, sweat and tears
to be industrious, rising early and going to bed late
to work hard without complaint (idiom)
responsible and diligent (idiom)
making an all-out effort (idiom); to try one's heart out/to do one's utmost
from distant parts
to stay up through the night (idiom)
